definition: lit. three monks have no water to drink (idiom)/fig. everybody's business is nobody's business/(If there is one monk, he will fetch water for himself. If there are two, they will fetch water together. But if there are three or more, none will take it upon himself to fetch water.)
pinyin: san1 ge4 he2 shang5 mei2 shui3 he1

definition: surname San
three/3
variant of 個|个[ge4]
individual/this/that/size/classifier for people or objects in general
to combine a powdery substance (flour, plaster etc) with water/Taiwan pr. [huo4]
to compose a poem in reply (to sb's poem) using the same rhyme sequence/to join in the singing/to chime in with others
old variant of 和[he2]/harmonious
surname He/Japanese (food, clothes etc)
old variant of 和[he2]
to mix (ingredients) together/to blend/classifier for rinses of clothes/classifier for boilings of medicinal herbs
to complete a set in mahjong or playing cards
and/together with/with/sum/union/peace/harmony/Taiwan pr. [han4] when it means "and" or "with"

(negative prefix for verbs)/have not/not
drowned/to end/to die/to inundate

definition: lit. a child who cries gets to feed at the breast (idiom)/fig. the squeaky wheel gets the grease
pinyin: hui4 ku1 de5 hai2 zi5 you3 nai3 chi1

definition: lit. the mountain can't have two tigers (idiom)/fig. this town ain't big enough for the two of us/(of two rivals) to be fiercely competitive
pinyin: yi1 shan1 bu4 rong2 er4 hu3

definition: three men talking makes a tiger (idiom); repeated rumor becomes a fact
lit. sandpiper and clam war together and the fisherman catches both (idiom); fig. neighbors who can't agree lose out to a third party
pinyin: yu4 bang4 xiang1 zheng1 , yu2 weng1 de2 li4

definition: it's the most capable people who do the most work (idiom) (intended as consolation for the overworked, or flattery when making a request etc)

Kong Rong giving up pears, classic moral story about Kong Rong 孔融[Kong3 Rong2] picking up smaller pears while leaving the bigger ones to his older brothers, still used nowadays to educate the young on courtesy and modesty
egalitarianism
lit. to try to make an ox drink by forcing its head down to the water (idiom)/fig. to try to impose one's will on sb
pinyin: niu2 bu4 he1 shui3 qiang3 an4 tou2

definition: when everybody gathers fuel, the flames are higher (idiom)/the more people, the more strength
pinyin: zhong4 ren2 shi2 chai2 huo3 yan4 gao1

definition: mutually shirking responsibilities (idiom); each blaming the other/passing the buck to and fro/each trying to unload responsibilities onto the other
tragedy of the commons (economics)
unity is strength (revolutionary slogan and popular song of 1943)
pinyin: tuan2 jie2 jiu4 shi4 li4 liang5

definition: lit. the butt governs the head (idiom)/fig. where one stands depends on where one sits/one's views are shaped by one's circumstances
pinyin: pi4 gu5 jue2 ding4 nao3 dai5

definition: common saying/proverb
the shot hits the bird that pokes its head out (idiom)/nonconformity gets punished
